reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a quite interesting project so far and it's going to be even more promising in the future.
Pros:
- Two big modes are sure to make it into the release build: Singleplayer Campaign Mode (somewhat close to the BI classical campaigns) and Multiplayer Campaign (imagine a Clash of Clans in WWII setting... without constant donations reminder and the urge to watch the progress of your base each few hours).
- Classical isometric view on warm and homey 2,5D graphics. Just like the old times, but with better effects.
- Rock, Paper, Scissors gameplay in a whole - vehicles are good at destroying defences, infantry has something for everyone (apart from defences), and defences/obstacles when put in place can cripple any advancing enemy.
- Developers are listening to the community, setting the highest priority to bug hunting and making the most wanted features come out first.
- Great oldschool music, artwork, map decorations (some - with borderline humour)... You'll like it when you notice it :)

Contras:
- It's not BI as I thought it would be. Don't get me wrong - It's a fun game to play, but it's just not Blitzkrieg I. Not yet.
- BIII is kinda poorly balanced on higher, advanced levels. I believe it will be fixed soon, but atm t5+ of the headquarters can be pain (imagine fighting Pershings with your KV-1s).
- It's still Early Access. Expect to have some minor pathfinding bugs (I've met no other).

Overall result?
I'd say it's 7/10 for old Blitzkrieg players, 8/10 for Clash of Clans players and 9/10 for those dissapointed in Company of Heroes 2 fantasy-like setting (such as myself).

Update 11.24.2015
Game has surely evolved a lot since the last time I've launched it in the September. All sorts of improvements are here and ready to go:
1. Pathfinding got fixed in a small unit groups. Yes, tactical combat still requires a lot of micromanaging but hey, it's what the Blitzkrieg series was about since like forefer.
2. Developers really DO listen to the Community. All of the suggestions I've made as a regular Community member were answered to. Some made it into the game (like treating fortifications as if those were units in the means of a balance).
3. Generals provide a unique experience with each and every faction. You can customize both your army now and the defences of your base like you see fit.
4. Most balance issues are now gone, whilst 'Sauron's eye' should be fixed IMAO. It is a little bit too much OP.
5. Numerous UI improvements here and there finally made the game easy to navigate.
6. Should be first, actually... Now you can switch maps in Multiplayer Campaign. Yes. You can.

Blitzkrieg 3 - Review
Story:
Blitzkrieg 3 takes place in WWII Europe, where you control three forces through their battles:
Germany conquering France, Russia conquering Germany and America fighting for Sicily.

Gameplay:
In singleplayer, the game is a typical RTS, you command units, that are either added to your forces by you freeing them, fullfilling objectives or just as reinforcements. You have no impact on the types of units that your army is made of, so you basically have to adapt to your army, and not the other way around.
The three nations have the same units, maybe with minimal slight variations, but the overall gameplay is the same for all. And this is where strategy comes in:
The game is basically beatable with very few, very basic strategies, once you learned an effective way to defend/attack you can always go back to that, since
all nations play the same. Thus the singleplayer is nothing special.
The multiplayer on the other hand features something very unusual for this genre: You are provided with a base, the size of which grows with your level,
that you need to build up and defend with units and structures from other players. Upon an enemy attacking, your units are controlled by AI. You gain resources
over time, that you can use to buy and upgrade units and structures. When attacking, you are matched against a random player of similar level and have to fight their setup. It is an interesting concept, very often seen in mobile games.

Pros:
+Nice graphics, creating a fitting atmosphere
+Troops speak in their native language

Neutral:
~The multiplayer gameplay is new for this genre, but often seen on mobile devices
~Singleplayer offers nothing special

Cons:
-The singleplayer is very basic
-All nations play the same
-There is no straightup 1v1 battle

Conclusion:
I don't think I can give this game just one score, so I went ahead to give it a singleplayer-rating and a multiplayer-rating:
Singleplayer: 6.5/10
Multiplayer: 8.5/10

I was hesitant at first to review Blitzkrieg 3, due to its “mixed” reviews on Steam. But given that it’s still in development, I figured I’d give it a shot, and I’m glad I did.

Blitzkrieg 3 is a fantastic strategy game, with features I haven’t seen elsewhere. The key thing to remember is that it’s not Company of Heroes. It isn’t about moving your troops cover-to-cover. It’s about blitzkrieg—lightning war. It’s Patton’s no “holding ground” strategy, and the strategy that allowed the then-evil Germans to steamroll half of Europe.

It also doesn’t feel like a WWII game. You can play as Americans and still fight against Americans, and the same goes for the Soviets and Germans. It feels more like a post-apocalyptic war-game with WWII weapons, where you build your defenses and raid the camps of neighboring tribes.

Now that we have that out of the way, let’s get to the point: these factors are what makes Blitzkrieg 3 fun. While one side needs to try and plow through the enemy, the other side needs to build a base to defend against the attack, and this means finding all kinds of creative ways to ambush them.

The game starts with you at your base. You get a set number of fuel and supplies to spend on upgrading building and units, or on your defenses. The base building is a game in itself, because your base is technically a full map that other players can attack at any moment.

Think of it like Home Alone, only with tanks and guns.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As an early access game, Blitzkrieg 3 has a lot going for it.  However, early access also implies that you'll be receiving an incomplete or flawed experience from that of a retail (launch) game.  All of that said, I will try my best to provide an unbiased and objective review, detailing the qualities and deficits that Blitzkrieg 3 currently has.

Pros:

[+] Excellent graphics.  Beautiful, highly detailed maps--there are animals, roaming vehicles (trains, cars, etc.), and people who are doing daily tasks.  Trees fall down as tanks run into them, fortifications explode and crumble, and shots richochet off of vehicles creating an impressive realism.

[+] Base building.  Organizing your upgrades is always fun.  There are tradeoffs to consider as you are leveling up, because you can't possibly level everything up at once.  Do you want improved infantry?  How so?  Do you work on individual upgrades to existing units, do you upgrade research options or upgrade the barracks itself?   The tradeoffs aslo exist in how you upgrade your defenses.  Do you want a widespread defensive network, or do you want a few key structures that are hihgly upgraded?  The options are impressive.

[+] Strategy.  Despite what others are saying, there are lots of strategic options that open up conisderably the more you unlock and play.
-Command points can be spent on a variety of support options.
-Artillery to weaken defenses
-Smoke screen to hide advances
-Spies to scout the bases
-Reinforcements

[+] Army composition.  The options are pretty limitless here.  There are four classifications of vehicles and five classifications of infantry, and determining how many of each can be a very important decision going into battle.

Cons:

[!] Pathfinding.  This is something that will presumably get better over time, but right now tank pathfinding is horrendous, at times.  This becomes even more apparent the larger the vehicle is.  And taking into account that as you upgrade your vehicles, you replace them with a larger chasis (stug to jadgpanther for instance), this makes it even more problematic.

[!] No expanded multiplayer options.  Currently, there's only 1 v 1 asychronous battles.  I love the asynchronous battles, by the way, but I'd love to see 2 v 2 and greater options implemented.

[!] Building off the above, there are no integrated community options.  No friends list, no chat system, no way to invite others to look at your base and basically zero player-to-player communication.  [This is a huge negative]

[!] A lack of unit explanations.  I would love to see a detailed tactical tutorial or in-game guide.  Right now I have no idea how to use an MG squad versus an assault squad versus a normal rifleman squad.  All three seem relatively samey
date: and I don't have a clue what their operational differences are (if any) besides different stat adjustments.

I heartily recommend holding off on this purchase at the time of writing.

I see potential in this game. While the people comparing this to offline defence mobile games are not wrong, I believe this kind of gameplay can be an engaging experience. Others will talk about high-level balance, but I have only been able to sink a short time into this game due to the following concerns:

1) Unclear instruction. The tutorial currently gives brief highlights of where the first couple of buttons to press are, but after that, nothing. It is a trial-and-error system to figure out what you must do. I was confused. Still am, although after two hours I think I have most of the interface figured out.

2) Bugs. Yes, the game is early access. But you knew that, it's an early access review. Regardless of the release state of the game, I am here to say that the current state of bugginess impacts the playabilty of the game. Objectives dissapear from your screen and there appears to be no way to get them back. Unit pathfinding struggles immensely. You cannot target units behind buildings (you will target the building itself). There appears to be no way to adjust a unit's heading when controlling it in battle, causing micromanagement dances when trying to get a tank to stop reversing into the enemy.

3) The game seems to spazz out pretty horribly if you have a less-than-stellar internet connection. I have a less-than-stellar connection, but I am able to play other online games without major issue. This game freezes near-constantly, and for seconds at a time while playing. Worse, it does this WHEN TESTING AGAINST YOUR OWN BASE. Meaning, even what should be a local single-player experience appears to communicate through the game's servers.

4) Attack/Defence balance does seem to be massively off, though others with more time in the game will have better opinions on this. Simply put, the defender and attacker appear to get the same number of units. As any RTS player will tell you, this is an automatic win for any semi-competent attacker. Concentrate on one point in the enemy's defences, and it's pretty much right-click to win. The attacker can even continue to call up reinforcements to replace any lost units.

Until such time as all of these issues are resolved, I must strongly advise against purchasing this game.

Early Access Constructive Criticism :D No Donkey sh1it!

1.	To my pleasant surprise, the narrative in the tutorial mission alternated between Russian, German and American forces. I love the way the developers choose to give different perspectives during the same session. It’s an interesting way of displaying what kind of impact, your actions have on your foe, as the perspective changes.

As you get the chance to play thru the eyes of your rival, you immediately see the aftereffect of your consequences. It’s a new take on storytelling, it’s very entertaining and refreshing.

2.	Cool moments: During a tutorial mission, you are given a few German infantry to clear out a poor Russian village. And here I was, in the middle of nowhere… hoping to spread democracy. Oh, well! We musn't disappoint our fuhrer, maybe we will find some MANA vodka.

I split my infantry into two squads. I started off by sending squad one to occupy an empty house on the outskirts of the village. This immediately started a firelight, my first squad was taking incoming fire from a house further up the street.

I tactically maneuvered my second squad thru a forest into an assaulting position on the flank. Using the new ability “assault building”, my second squad dashed forward out of the bushes into the house, screaming, pulling ears and vomiting on a chicken, ending up with five Russian KIA inside, oh and we found really fluffy teddy bear in the basement, to celebrate our victory, my heroic soldiers baptized it PUTIN.

3.	Sniper Unit - Sounds inaccurate in game. Last time I checked, yelling wasn’t part of the sniper weapons inventory. I swear to God, every time you give the sniper an order the dude goes ape sh1it, and starts screaming patriotic slogans.

The entire idea of having a dedicated unit going stealth, is silence. At least put some effort into making him act covert and whisper in response. Small changes to sound, can make a big difference to the atmosphere and characteristics of a unit.

4.	There seems to be no function at the moment to see your troops behind objects. And with such a rich and beautifully detailed environment, sometimes it’s hard to pinpoint your units in the field, you constantly need to reselect the units to find them.

Sorry, but I don’t want to spend my time searching for my troops on the battlefield. Especially when there is a mission timer involved.  Some sort of highlight is needed to distinguish your troops from the background, Men of war dose this brilliantly. Take note.

5.	Ability “About face” - Being a Company of Heroes player for many years. I found myself selecting a vehicle and trying to drag the front armoured part towards the enemy. I’m abruptly, startled and confused when I realise that no such function is available in Blitzkrige 3.

It’s 2015, happy new year! Ability’s like “About face” should be at my fingertips, and not hidden away in the far-flung-bottom right hand corner of the UI menu.

Yes, yes, I know! There is a Hot Key, you can press “R”. But that’s so… 2005, I’m not stating that simplification is bad. But coming from a CoH frame of mind, my RTS behaviour is tuned to having fast and responsive controls. In the current state, I don’t feel that responsiveness is coming thru in Blitzkrige 3.

I know there is a red compass-marker you can utilise to set your vehicles direction, but that option is way too sluggish and clumsy to use. Having an instant clock, with an arch of fire, popup underneath your vehicle is faster and better way to do it.

Why not include a more fine-tuned approach of controlling your vehicles for those that want that possibility. Instead of this barebones, point and click. There is definitely room for improvements to be made regarding this issue.

6.	At the current state Blitzkrige 3 does not offer any cover system for infantry. This is something that we should expect by today’s standards. There is a missed opportunity here in NOT letting the player use destructive environments as part of cover.

A lot of effort has gone into creating a detailed destructive environment for Blitzkrige 3. And the developers have succeeded. I just wish the developers made the collateral damage more than just eye candy.

Let me illustrate an example.  - Battle for Monte Casino, On 15 February 1944 the abbey was almost completely destroyed in a series of heavy American-led air raids. The bombing was conducted because many reports from troops on the ground suggested that Germans were occupying the monastery, and it was considered a key observational post by all those who were fighting in the field.

Only after the bombing were the ruins of the monastery occupied by German Fallschirmjäger (paratroopers), aiding them in their defence, because the ruins provided excellent defensive cover.

The point I’m making, is that the destructive environment in Blitzkrige 3 could have been utilized to benefit both sides. This could have created some unique variation of strategies in battles. What you get instead is repetitive gameplay, with limited paths of approach.

7.	Which brings me to my next point, I find it odd that the developers of Blitzkrige 3 strongly incentivise the concept of artificial intelligence for defensive purposes, in base mode. Calling it “core component of the multiplayer experience.”

Yet, the game is lacking any meaningful Ai behaviour, the way Ai responds to human players is with basic triggers, which activate on conditions. Example: A is true, there for activate B and repeat, basically.

Someone once said, “The best defence is an offense!” So far, I haven’t found any way to change Ai behaviour perimeters when defending your base to aggressive stance or turtle defensive, hit and run or balanced tactics.

It’s not fair to say that the Ai is inadequate. It dose its job, but it doesn’t like to deviate from a set path. Doing anything complicated like taking the initiative or making a surprise manoeuvre is out of the question. It’s all scripted and predictable behaviour, don’t expect to encounter General Rommel in the field, anytime soon.

8.	One more thing, the tip popup in the tutorial disappears to fast, it’s stressful and should be fix. This problem is especially hard on new players, who are trying to learn the game.  Your popups don’t have “next tip” or a “back to previous tip” buttons. WHY! WWwwwwhhhyy!!! WHHHHHYYY!!!!... . .. .why!

9.	OMG! I have no idea what the designers or concept artist were smoking when they created this Modern-bluish-sci-fi-metallic-transformers looking UI menu, I’m pretty sure it wasn’t water vapour. For the LOVE of GOD, the current UI doesn’t fit the WW2 themed framework at all, change it.

Other than that, it’s a good early access start.

Dont forget to thumbs up if you like my preview and would like to see more. Dont be a stranger leave a comment. Cheers 4 reading.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many of the reviews I have seen have most of the same complaints that I have for the most part. Yes it is very pretty, everything looks fantastic, especially the buildings with the idle soldiers just about, but that is probably one of its strongest features is how pretty it is.

Currently it feels lacking in content, and while it can be said that this is an early access game, so are other titles with more content and that do not feel like a ww2 version of clash of clans.

Now I have not tried out the historical battles yet, because the first one is just a wave defense and currently, I have zero desire to play a wave defense. There is no other way to see if there are any other battles because it just takes you straight into it. No single player besides that really. From what I have seen so far it doesnt look like there are any custom commanders to level up either. Nor any interactive campaign map on the multiplay side, just build a base and attack people, which just feels so uninspired that I honenestly thought that I would have to wait hours for my buildings to upgrade unless I bought a premium currency.

There really is not much of a cover system, so if you were thinking of company of heroes where you can hide behind a wall and throw grenades over it not really going to happen. While it does feel like it plays like blitzkrieg 2, it plays like blitzkrige 2. The controls are very similar without much improvement, as many other criticized the fact that you cannot face tanks, and you cant. I actually had a panzer one driving backwards until it spotted an enemy then decided to turn around.

Blitztkrieg one and two are fantastic games, but just little tweaks here and there to fix old controls and such would be fantastic. The graphics are all nice and good so they got that part down. Another thing is a lack of an ability to actually call in reinforcements which I guess is because of their strange multiplayer not a campagin campaign thing that they have going.  Multiplayer is not an instant make a game better solution, and when done improperly makes things worse.
Seeing as I have had many reservations about early access, the reason why I bought this was actually for the blitzkrieg one and two anthologies that I got with it and decided to give this a try anyways.

Overal, this game needs a lot more work. It is dreadfully lacking in content and the fact that It is missing so much customization and single player aspects is very worrysome.
There is no way I could recommend this game. Even just as a first impression I cannot recommend it, because you could buy far better things worth your time and money.

That being said, I really want this game to succeed. I really do, the market is so lacking in rts, that people are recommend turnbased games because there is not anything else out there that is decent beside company of heores, total war, and starcraft. Plus I love blitzkrieg, and the opportunity to see a new one would be amazing. Right now however, this is just a sad shell of something much better.

So far so fun for a early acces game. It sure is not Blitzkrieg at all anymore but it still makes for a decent and addicting game. Conquering the bases that other players created, each and everyone different from one another proved to be just as exciting as the constantly new possibilities in moba games. Lets see how long this game can hold me. For now, it gets a recommend, the price of 30€ isn't much and the content is there even if unfinished and a tad broken.

I hope the publishers take care of the future development of this game, so I don't have to change my review into a negative one. Therefore for anyone reading this, this review should be taken with the fact in mind that this game is in alpha status and that I, as of writing this, really enjoyed the 8hours I've spent so far with this game but might change my mind in the next few months unless I see progress.

My biggest issues with this game are the lack of actual RTS elements. While range indicators are involved the basic combat system breaks down to rock, paper, siscors. The strategic part of the game lacks depth and needs drastic improvement. The movement too, Infantry should have different movement speeds based on gear and vehicles especially, should be fixed.
The motions feel too clunky and units don't behave realistically.
I also want more control over my units. I want to tell my Infantry when to charge, get down or use items. The armies aren't that big that a little more mircomanagement would hurt.
Further the graphics are 'okay' but the sound needs improvement. Not just the ambience but the weapon and gear sounds as well.

For anyone whining about it not Blitzkrieg, youre right, get over it, its still a decent start and the brand 'blitzkrieg' doesn't belong to you. Thats life, thats gaming, accept it - Singleplayer is still similar to the old games so enjoy that. Otherwise I recommend you Men of War or the first CoH, but stay away from CoH2.

I'll say it one last time, if you're not okay with playing unfinished games, don't buy this - yet. However if you have no problem with that and you enjoy ARCADE RTS you're good to buy this already.

Well being a huge fan of rts I was excited to see the best world war II strategy game first hand. And it of course fell short of that statement. I still find men of war to rule the ww2 strategy title and this game isn't knocking it any time soon. The game has several elements I enjoy and around the same amount I hate.

Starting on a positive note the game functions and works and the gameplay is pretty fast paced. at ten minute around quick wits and lighting strategy is required, so prepare your blitzkrieg tactics. there is an extensive upgrade tree it's almost redic how much you have to do to upgrade your base. Resources are so abundant and yet it can take awhile to accumulate  them, at first it world make sense to fight battles because they are pretty easy. I was stomping the crud out so many people. but later on is where the game picks up and you will find yourself struggling to complete the same task you found easy at first.


That being said it's boasted a-sync multiplayer is fancy for clash of clans style. Which is a little sad, hopefully a full fledged pvp head to head battle mode will surface, but for now get ready for ai battles. I have to admit the appeal of the game comes in spurts, this is more of a time waster then a game you want to spend hours playing. and after around 50 battles it gets dry and you pick up on most of the tactics defenders will use. The problem is you will face battles you can't win due to the leveling system. Trying to rush to the next tier leaves you vulnerable to players who just have better stuff and I found that not upgrading my units was leading to my units not being able to fight what should have been a sure match from prior battles.  It's weird when you run into the same tank you killed a million times but this time it barely takes dmg and wrecks you. The rts mode is pretty good even if it is ai you get control where your defenses are, what they are ect. You can deploy defensive structures(barbed wire, mines, hedgehogs, bunkers, ect.) and then a battle group (infantry, tanks) buildings can be garrisoned and you can test your defenses to see what other players might do to you. you can also watch replays which is important if you don't want bleed resources like a stuck pig.

I enjoy the game and recommend it for those players looking to kill time and want to experience what it would be like if a mobile phone game sexed up sudden strike and produced a decent game.   However this is no company of heroes or even old blitzkrieg (which comes with it) so all is forgiven.

I've only played a few missions thus far but my first impressions are generally positive. I've always enjoyed the Blitzkrieg games and was excited when I saw this one.  Gameplay is generally similar to the previous ones, but it has better graphics. It most assuredly needs a 'save' option, as it's annoying to have to quit mid-mission and then have to start the whole mission over again. I also miss the variable stance option for infantry where they automatically go prone when under fire. I'm not fond of the new system where auxilliaries (air and fire support) are on a separate tab rather than displayed on the same screen as one's troops, but I can learn to live with it if it doesn't change.  So far there's no means of selecting which reinforcements you recieve-don't know if that's because it's no longer there or I just haven't progressed far enough for it to be an option, but if it is gone, I'd like it back.  Overall, I'd say if you liked the previous games you'll probably like this one.

Now back to conquering/liberating Europe . . .

Okay, so a few more things that need to be added from BK2. Infantry need to be able to entrench as do vehicles, or at least enter pre-prepared trenches. One of the weaknesses of BK1 and BK2 was the vulnerability of infantry which was partially corrected by the ability to dig in when under fire. Right now they're completely exposed and die like flies. Likewise, it looks like the ability to summon reinforcements is not yet present and it needs to be.


I have fought the Arras mission six or seven times now and I always end up trying (and failing) to take the bridge with one damaged tank and 3 badly wounded infantry because I lost the others trying to take on five or six Char B1, one of the most heavily armoured tanks at the beginning of the war with a hull mounted 75mm gun.  In its present state, I would consider the Arras mission virtually unwinnable unless you have LOTS of luck on your side.  Also captured weapons-mortars, anti-tank weapons, et hoc genus omne used to be movable either by infantry or by vehicle and they should be again. I would also like to see a separate and distinct German and a distinct Allies campaign.

Early Access Review

My review will change as I'm reviewing in a bit early but as of now I have to Not Recommend this game. It's not worth $30.00USD in its current state as it still feels like a browser game and the fact that the main focus is on quick PvP skrimishes against other bases. While a single player mode is present it's pretty bland and dumbed down, compared to the previous games. They seem to have gone a different route from the originals being more tactical and drawn out to now matches only last but 5 - 10 minutes because of such a small fighting area. Not to mention the fact that eventually you can just call in artillery where ever you want and your defenses are usually destroyed within one barrage, which I don't like the fact that you can just call in a set amount of artillery EVERY time. It would be nice if it wasn't even present or have restrictions on it to make the game a little more tactical. I recommend this game under $15 at least, however the main reason I dislike and cannot recommend this game is mostly due to the fact that it's so browser-like. I hope when the game is out of Early Access it will have improved upon that and made it more like an actual game and not something like Forge of Empires.

It really isn't a bad game, it has promise and the graphics are surprisingly good (the tanks bounce around a little too much though IMO.) But it certainly isn't worth the current price, maybe when it's out of Early Access it will be worth the $30, but as of now, no. If another sale for all three games comes along I recommend picking that up as you can get all three for less than the current listing of this game single. And the first one is very good if you like the old time RTS games.

This game is disapointing.  I did spent quite some time playing this game hoping it will get better as I progress. I finally gave up after spending over 30 hours on it.  First of all, all three factrions have the same unit types.  Tanks and infantry units do look different among US, Russia and Germany, but those units are the same type of heavy tank, tank destroyer, assault infantry and regullar infantry, etc.  They just look different but are with the same functions.  The buildings, defense units and structures look the same among all three factions.

Multiplayer is a waste of time.  The upgrading system and game progress take forever.  It takes around 600k - 800k supply to progress from a level 5 headquarter to a level 6 headquarter, and each battle won will give you only about 7k of supply.  You fight in the maps with defenses created by other players.  However, there are only a few player created defense maps (around 4-5 per level).  So you fight the same battle over and over.  Imagine fighting the exact same battle 20 times hoping to get enough supply to upgrade to the next level.

Another disappointment is that you will lose your supply to other player when your defense (controlled by AI) is breached while you are offline.   Lastly, this game is buggy.  For example, units don't respond to command, infantry won't be able to destroy road blocks as that's suppose to be one of their skill.  So it ended up my whole army got stucked and I won't be able to finish the battle.

However, I must say the graphics are nice and the sound effects are good.  But unfortunatly, the gameplay is boring with repeatable maps and opponents.  I would not recommend this game to anyone at this stage of the game development.  Save your money for something else.

I wouldn't buy the game in its current state.   List of problems that I have found with it:

1. The game lacks multiplayer matches, because more people choose to play the AI instead of you. No multiplayer games is a game killer if you ask me. I can't sit there for hours waiting for 1 match.  Sure its fun setting up a defense, but if you have to beg people to attack you forget about it.
2. The game progresses to a level 7 where you get to unlock all the different units, but you can never go back to a lower tier which are quite fun, and compete for that level ranking. They need to add in a change to any tier level ranking game.
3.  The game needs an option to play any map of your choosing.   This right here is probably the most desired want.
4. No way to save your maps once you have spent hours setting up your defense, because they make you upgrade to a higher level. And all that work is gone forever.
5. No team games yet.  That is unlike the Blitzkrieg people to not have this option.

There are many other problems with this game like game balancing issues but they are minor compared to the problem of finding people to play matches with you. There is no 'set up a match' thing button that you see in most games.  All you do is set up your defenses on a map and wait for people to attack you,.. that can be 5 minutes waiting or 24 hours to 1 week.

There are some very good positives also, one being there is no base buiding like in COH where you can keep bringing up reinfocements.  I don't really likes neverending games.

Most of my buddies left this game out of frustration. and I think its happening to me too.

Early Access Review

Why do the developers want us to follow their idea of how the game should be played? Again this is another RTS that forces you to follow a script. Some of the best RTS games I have ever played allowed me to control the game. Set an objective and then the player can follow whatever strategy he or she deems fit to achieve that goal.

This channelled game play is not fun, I don’t care that I have to take item 1 then item 2 then item 3 I want to arrive a successful outcome MY way.

Had the potential to be a good game along the lines CoH or MoW but they missed the boat here – developers please stop trying to force us to play YOUR version of the game. Allow people free reign over the game so we can play how WE want to.

It is an alright game, but if I was back and knew now how they structured the game play, I would not be spending any money on it, if I could I would try for a refund I feel that disappointed with this game.
